timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		<exemplarCharacters>[a á à b d e é è ẹ f g {gb} h i í ì j k l m n ń o ó ò ọ p r s ṣ t u ú ù w y]</exemplarCharacters>
          
          
            
            		<exemplarCharacters>[a á à b d e é è ẹ {ẹ\u0301} {ẹ\u0300} f g {gb} h i í ì j k l m n ń o ó ò ọ {ọ\u0301} {ọ\u0300} p r s ṣ t u ú ù w y]</exemplarCharacters>
timeline.author: srl295
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -716,7 +716,7 @@ CLDR data files are interpreted according to the LDML specification (http://unic
 		</codePatterns>
 	</localeDisplayNames>
 	<characters>
-		<exemplarCharacters>[a á à b d e é è ẹ {ẹ\u0301} {ẹ\u0300} f g {gb} h i í ì j k l m n o ó ò ọ {ọ\u0301} {ọ\u0300} p r s ṣ t u ú ù w y]</exemplarCharacters>
+		<exemplarCharacters>[a á à b d e é è ẹ f g {gb} h i í ì j k l m n ń o ó ò ọ p r s ṣ t u ú ù w y]</exemplarCharacters>

replies.bodyText:
per @moyogo https://unicode-org.atlassian.net/browse/CLDR-13622?focusedCommentId=157872 - this results in only adding ń
I can't comment on [ḿ {m\u0300} ǹ] but the comment in the spreadsheet seems to imply that ǹ is not used in modern practice.
replies.author: srl295

replies.bodyText:
Annemarie was tasked with getting this reviewed, and the linguist feedback was in https://unicode-org.atlassian.net/browse/CLDR-13622?focusedCommentId=157640. That is:

(3) The nasal n is also marked with a high tone mark in syllabic nasal context (i.e ń.kọ́, ń.lọ) or with a mid tone mark - unmarked as said before (i.e n.kò) in the negative form.
However, it does look like there is good evidence tor retaining the 0300/1 combinations.
replies.author: macchiati

replies.bodyText: I'm happy to follow up to get feedback based on the latest comments. I agree though that if there are examples of the characters being used in multiple Yoruba documents and websites we should definitely consider retaining those combinations.
replies.author: AEApple
srl295

timeline.message:
CLDR-13622 common/main/yo.xml

restore combinations with 0300/1

Co-authored-by: Steven R. Loomis <srl295@gmail.com>
